title: Before 1 January 2021, will the People's Liberation Army (PLA) and/or People’s Armed Police (PAP) be mobilized in Hong Kong?
preds:
Hong Kong is still relevant due to its open financial markets and connection to International instruments and China needs to internationalise its currency. China now controls Hong Kong politically, introduced  its security law and ignored any treaties, so an invasion of armed forces is probably not necessary.
http://www.iberchina.org/files/2017/china_2021_chatham.pdf

Hong Kong’s highest court upholds ban on masks at protests - The Washington Post
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/hongkong-mask-ban-ruling/2020/12/20/f2722af0-4340-11eb-a277-49a6d1f9dff1_story.html
Mon, 21 Dec 2020 06:45:00 GMT
New years is a major holiday season.  I don't see any reason for police to stir up things at this point.

Compared to earlier in the year, now that China has tightened its grip in Hong Kong (cancelling elections and imprisoning activists), if a large scale riot were to occur, it would be more likely for China to send in the PLA. However, even though elections have been canceled and activists have been imprisoned, there have been no large scale riots in response. This is likely due to:
- COVID
- economy was in shambles after months of protests, the people are tired and want peace/order
- those who can leave are getting ready to (UK passports) Unless China does something really drastic to severely aggravate the people during the remaining time before the end of the year, and the people respond in a large scale riot, and the leadership of China believe a PLA response is adequate
OR
Some severe COVID or natural disaster scenario,
China will not send in the PLA/PAP into Hong Kong before the end of the year.

Hong Kong police arrest 8 over university protest - ABC News
https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/hong-kong-police-arrest-university-protest-74577778
Mon, 07 Dec 2020 11:04:36 GMT Hong Kong construction worker gets 40 months for tossing petrol bomb at protest - South China Morning Post
https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3113637/hong-kong-protests-construction-worker-gets-40-months
Fri, 11 Dec 2020 11:54:28 GMT
Changing forecast due to passage of time

Reduced probability.  HK seems quiet, and I don't see any reason for China to press the students.  Geopolitical situation is disturbed (new US president and impacts on multiple players, just need to watch for any changes.

Hong Kong protest aftermath: what is top cop’s biggest challenge? - South China Morning Post.
https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3111717/aftermath-hong-kong-protests-top-cops-biggest
Mon, 30 Nov 2020 00:00:18 GMT
 Pretty chilling:
> These days, he said, residents from all walks of life spread untrue posts and anti-police messages on an unprecedented scale over social media.
> As of the end of October, 10,148 people aged 11 to 84 had been arrested in connection with the social unrest and almost a quarter had been prosecuted. Of the 726 people already dealt with, over four-fifths were convicted, with the stiffest penalty being a four-year prison sentence.
> Of the 124 letters sent by police to media to refute false or biased reports, 105 (85 per cent), went to Chinese-language newspaper Apple Daily, which regularly splashed reports alleging police brutality or wrongdoing on its front page.
> Tang said: “A powerful person who controls a media organisation openly requested foreign countries to sanction Hong Kong and China. Everyone knows about it.”
> He refrained from naming Apple Daily founder Jimmy Lai Chee-ying when he accused “media forces” of sabotaging police efforts to enforce the law. Lai was arrested in August under the national security law for alleged collusion with foreign forces. Can't believe that they actually used "untruths". Joshua Wong and fellow activists plead guilty in Hong Kong protests trial - BBC News
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-55039622
Mon, 23 Nov 2020 08:00:00 GMT

I was worried about the wording of this question after hearing the democratic opposition in have resigned from the Legislative Council in protest and there have been Chinese officials using language suggesting Beijing will begin passing legislation affecting HK.  There's a higher chance the PAP or PLA will be legally garrisoned in HK before year's end, but I still don't think there is a good chance they will be mobilized.

Going to update my forecast a bit to incorporate US election status.  Do the Chinese government push harder/faster (message to Taiwan)?, or sit and see what happens?  I'm thinking they feel no pressure to move quickly, and no obvious reason for the students to instigate until the end of the year.
Will China take advantage of current chaos in the US leadership?  To quote the Ghost Busters, "Who you gonna call?"

Activity seems to heating up, not just in Hong Kong, but overseas.  Reports of harassment of refugees from Hong Kong being harassed  for anti Party protests.  What I can't yet figure out is why?  The party has pretty solid control internally since Tiananmen Square, so what are they concerned about?  I'm bumping my probability to 10% to allow for the fog of war (not literally).

Hong Kong protests: Teen activist Tony Chung charged under Beijings national security law - Firstpost
https://www.firstpost.com/world/hong-kong-protests-teen-activist-tony-chung-charged-under-beijings-national-security-law-8962861.html
Thu, 29 Oct 2020 07:20:00 GMT
> Chung and three other members of Student Localism were first arrested by a newly created national security police unit in July on suspicion of inciting secession via social media posts.

China has gradually tightened its grip on HK without causing lots of international protests.  It does not need to involve the PLA to do the dirty work - there is plenty of police and HK government officials willing to do the work.  I hate to say it but democracy in HK is a lost cause.
Things seem quiet, no reason for protests or over-reactions right now.  Dropping my percentage more in line with the crowd until something else happens
The willing capitulation of Honk Kong to Chna makes this unlikely
Not required - Hong Kong is lost. Next up Taiwan.
Tweaking forecast down due to change in circumstances

"a year ago, hundreds of thousands of people joined unauthorised demonstrations calling for full democracy. Now only the very brave are prepared to protest without police approval ... Many of the activists involved in the unrest that swept Hong Kong for months last year are keeping their heads down ... So far, however, the [new national security] law has been sparingly applied. Hundreds of people have been arrested for protest-related offences since the central government in Beijing imposed the act on June 30th ... Only about 30 people have been arrested under the new law." https://www.economist.com/china/2020/10/08/hong-kongs-new-security-law-is-being-applied-sparingly-so-far So the new national security law has not been used much but still seems to be working as intended — as a strong deterrent against mass protests. The only situation in which it makes sense for the PLA or PAP to be mobilized in Hong Kong is in the event of such mass protests, and they would have to be larger/more intense than the mass protests that predate the national security law since even those did not prompt the mobilization of the PLA or PAP. I don't see such intense mass protests as at all likely in the near future.

It seems that the students have more to gain by initiating an event that would initiate mobilization than the government, so if I assign a 50% probability for students and a 10% for a government initiated event , I'm calculating about 35%.  If the students get more desperate as the government gets closer to full unification, or the students swell and get more support from 'common folk' or external support (British, USA, ?) probabilities of government action would be expected to go up.  I don't think the student probability can go much higher
Activity is about normal (for Hong Kong).  National Day celebrations did not massive protests.  Backing down my probability for now.

major Chinese holiday coming up, refugees at sea trying to escape, Chinese gov (?) may be feeling their control slipping and need to show some control.  Will protesters overplay their hand or lose control?  How will India play into the question? The pot is starting to bubble.  Interesting.

From the Economist 
“ Carrie Lam, the chief executive of Hong Kong, celebrated the city’s “return to stability” at a flag-raising ceremony for China’s National Day. Hundreds of police patrolled the streets, looking for signs of a banned pro-democracy demonstration that failed to materialise. Protests had been planned against the National Security Law and the arrest of 12 people who attempted to flee to Taiwan.”

No mention of PLA or PAP. Dissent definitely stifled/under control (depending on perspective).
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/oct/01/hong-kong-police-out-in-force-to-deter-protests-on-chinas-national-day

Staying at 1%. One country two systems dead. World preoccupied by COVID, elections,  populism, and fake/real news. Winnie The Pooh now installing Tigger, Piglet, Eeyore, Rabbit, Kangaroo, and Roo to keep an eye on Hong Kong...
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/28/who-runs-hong-kong-party-faithful-shipped-in-to-carry-out-beijing-will-security-law

Police states don’t require mobilization because there’s always an undercurrent of mobilization and repression. Winnie the Pooh is winning battles everywhere but longer term we’ll see where This ends. Thankfully some countries pushing back instead of kowtowing. 
https://www.wired.com/story/hong-kong-is-troubling-case-study-in-death-of-democracy/

China has its hands full in Tibet right now.  Granted, they have a lot of hands, but Hong Kong seems the least of their problems.  I think the probability is higher on the protesters side who may see an opportunity to take advantage of China's other issues, to improve their negotiation positions. 4 months to go, minus the holidays, crowd at 15%.  I'll split my forecast for now.

"Millions of Hong Kongers were supposed to vote in legislative council elections on Sunday. But in July, Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam delayed the elections for one year under the guise of a coronavirus public health threat. So instead of casting ballots, hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators took to the streets of Hong Kong on Sunday ... Sunday's protest was relatively small. However, the number of arrests was similar to that seen during last year's large-scale demonstrations ... Galileo Cheng, the social affairs executive for the Hong Kong Catholic Institution Staff Association, told DW that those who were still willing to join yesterday's protest, despite the national security law and the ban on public gathering, were well-prepared and more aggressive than normal protesters ... many peaceful protesters have been deterred by the pandemic and new rules not permitting demonstrations." https://www.dw.com/en/chinas-influence-changing-hong-kong-protests/a-54842597

"Police fired rounds of pepper balls at protesters in Hong Kong on Sunday and arrested almost 300 after demonstrators took to the streets to oppose the postponement of legislative elections and a new national security law imposed by China ... Anti-government demonstrations have declined this year mainly because of limits on group gatherings, imposed to counter the spread of coronavirus, and the security law, which punishes actions China sees as subversive, secessionist, terrorist or colluding with foreign forces." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-security-protests/hong-kong-police-fire-pepper-balls-at-protesters-opposed-to-election-delay-new-law-idUSKBN25X0AX

After much discussion in class about the rarity of Chinese military actions, and the steady downward trend of my fellow forecasters, I'm revising my submission down. I haven't had time to do any additional research, so this is really a vote of faith in the wisdom of crowds... the protests have been ongoing for more than a year, and China hasn't used military intervention to end them. As stated in my original forecast, and voiced by fellow forecasters, it seems likely China has refrained from military intervention in order to refute global political pressure with regards to its poor record on human rights issues... but I'm leaving a window open for the possibility that a triggering event in mainland China could lead to a crackdown in which China re-asserts control in Hong Kong in order to quell similar actions in China.
Creeping down as time moves on, it's unlikely to happen
Tweaking down forecast a bit as activity seems to be quelled for the moment.

The police have it under control and have broken the protest spirit. They are systemically arresting - possibly preemptively - all leaders. The police is now on the front door. There is no need to escalate and ask China for assistance.  In addition I don’t think the US is that keen to support “protestors” abroad whilst dealing with their own protestors in the US which will continue till the end of 2020
Lowering my forecast again - seems to be very low chance that China will mobilize PLP/PAP in Hong Kong to avoid bad media coverage & they haven't done do since 1997 (HK independence).

The relatively subdued reaction to arrests (e.g. Mr. Lai of Apple Daily), and pro-democracy groups disbanding (e.g. Demosisto) make future mass protests less likely. The PLA/PAP was not used despite protests following the new security law. Future use seems very unlikely, even if unrest starts to gain momentum again. Hugely reducing forecast.

Not impossible given Covid and other tensions in PRC, but steady news reports since the enactment of the National Security Law in Hong Kong have shown Pro-Democracy activists gradually shifting tactics to be less overt in response, lessening possibility of escalation by the deadline.

I've lowered my forecast after a training we had this week. In the time since Hong Kong was brought back into China, the PLA/PAP has not been mobilized. It seems more likely that China would place more resources in the Hong Kong police force in order to deal with future issues. This also seems like a time when China would prefer to stay out of the limelight. Protest activity in Belarus is already stealing the media away, and for China to mobilize the PLA/PAP would only invite press coverage. The press has already covered police brutality in Hong Kong, making it "old news." China and Hong Kong will likely delay any form of escalation as long as it continues to handle the problem and not draw new attention.

The pain is just stacking up. When it happens it will be a spectacle. But for when...
https://gcaptain.com/hong-kong-cruise-default/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Gcaptain+%28gCaptain.com%29&goal=0_f50174ef03-78532cfc83-170102337&mc_cid=78532cfc83&mc_eid=c74873c672
https://gcaptain.com/shipping-tax-exemptions-hong-kong/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Gcaptain+%28gCaptain.com%29&goal=0_f50174ef03-78532cfc83-170102337&mc_cid=78532cfc83&mc_eid=c74873c672

I am lowering my earlier forecast after our training and subsequent conversations this week. Given the fact that the PLA/PAP hasn't technically mobilized since 1997 and the protests this year are not as bad relative to earlier years, I think there is a small likelihood of mobilization. Though, PLA/PLP may covertly mobilize under the guise of local law enforcement agencies.
They may already be surreptitiously part of the HK police force.

I was just randomly thinking about this question. Why would China need to mobilize the PLA in HK? It did not need to use this option when the Legco was stormed and universities where under siege in 2019. With the new laws in place, this kind of popular uprising has become a lot less likely. So why provoke the general population, the United States, etc. by doing something so radical, if the HK police are perfectly capable of roughing up protesters, and the courts now provide a tool to lock up people indefinitely?
My theory is China is letting COVID in Hong Kong prevent mass protests in place of needing PLA / PAP.

China has refrained from military intervention for more than seven months, likely due to a desire to mitigate global political pressure to respect human rights. But China may also be feeling mounting internal pressure to "get this under control" in order to discourage nascent internal protest movements. If there is some internal triggering event (dissident arrest, political event, etc.) that generates greater support inside China for the Hong Kong protestors, China may feel compelled to act to shut down the protests.

The election may have some influence on this question, so am hesitant to give much more than a 50/50 probability. I believe China will have as many facts and best estimates before making a no return decision.
Pandemic often deeps societal points of strain and Hong Kong may be embolden by the other protests around the world. If protest resume we can assume the PLA will be mobilized.

Jimmy Lai, the founder of Hong Kong’s pro-democracy newspaper Apple Daily, was arrested and scores of police raided the paper’s headquarters Monday in the highest-profile case yet under Hong Kong’s new national security law. 8/11/20

While I believe these forces are already being ""mobilized" (actively engaged in military or law enforcement actions against protesters within the territory of Hong Kong)", you would guess my answer should be 100% yes.  However, will the threshold of evidence to include involvement be met?  I decided to go with 0% as the Chinese Communist Party will never openly admit it.  (little green men anyone?)

No time for analysis. Limited evidence without a chance to look at credibility/reliability suggests covert use of those assets as of this day. Would see expanded use of these assets in a covert/under plausible deniability rather than openly mobilized in active engagement. However, no idea what threshold on the ground in HK would trigger overwhelming open force, or what circumstances in the world (degree of paralysis among western governments on international issues due to COVID-19 - for instance), would signal use of open force. Taiwan anyone?

"The United States on Friday imposed sanctions on Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam, the territory’s current and former police chiefs and eight other top officials for what Washington says is their role in curtailing political freedoms in the territory ... A source familiar with the matter said U.S. deliberations on the sanctions intensified after Lam postponed a Sept. 6 election to Hong Kong’s legislature by a year because of a rise in coronavirus cases, dealing a blow to the pro-democracy opposition that had hoped to make huge gains." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-china-hong-kong-sanctions/us-imposes-sanctions-on-hong-kongs-lam-other-officials-over-crackdown-idUSKCN253215
Tweaking down a bit due to COVID  issues
The Secret Police are there but not PAP. https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/china-opens-hong-kong-headquarters-for-its-secret-police-2258937

Roughly 5.5 months for a  mobilization to occur.  New years a big milestone in both Hong Kong and Mainland China.  PAP has significant other commitments with the Uighur and Tibet problems.  Can they take on all three?  Once Xi gets started he needs to win it, or lose face.  Weather in January is warm, its also tourist season, so potential international issues if foreigners get caught up in Chinese military (or quasi military) efforts to control over Hong Kong's police, who 60% Hong Kong residents believe the police are a branch of the PAP already.  First estimate

If... China believes it is unable to assume satisfactory control, and make others around the world, Nations and their actors, believe it as well. For an authoritarian regime especially, combined with China's historical Mandate of Heaven giving the CCP leadership added legitimacy coming from a metaphysical source... which charges the leadership at any time to ensure prosperity or be illegitimate, China will do whatever it believes it has to do to maintain the mandate and maintain control of its dominions. Hong Kong, is viewed as a prelude to Taiwan, to fail here in gaining and maintaining control by any means will delegitimize their stated goal, and place the regime in an unacceptable position that can only be avoided through unquestionable assertion of authority through force.

I am going to assume that the question is to determine whether a mainland Chinese overwhelming force will take over and take control (officially) from the Hong Kong authorities.
According to reports the PLA and PAP already have a presence in Hong Kong in either a support or monitoring effort.
Us military power, UK ex-colonial power, Australia regional strategic power and Canada are starting to increase their pressure on China by restricting visas, ceasing extradition treaties and offering resident/citizen visas to Hong Kong people.
The U.S. is withdrawing special country status from China that diminishes its role as a global financial hub.
Huawei telecommunications equipment is being deleted or restricted  as a supplier to the Five eyes intelligence group.
The credibility of the Chinese government has been eroded due its handling of the coronavirus pandemic.
Brunei, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Vietnam have been treated with disdain by China in a dispute over the South China sea islands showing the Chinese governments influence as a superpower.
It is a matter of honour for China to reclaim Hong Kong as it was taken by a dominant colonial power and funded by drug money by supplying opium to their people to subjugate them. China now has the power to take control of its own destiny and a lessening need for HK.
Hong Kong is still a financial hub, albeit diminishing due to rise of Shanghai and with Singapore in the background; China will need to dismantle the Hong Kong administration step by step.
An overt invasion of Hong Kong by the PLA/PAP would be a massive PR disaster (Tiananmen Square) and is not necessary.
China has the power; HK has no military force of its own and can be assimilated into China step by step and at China’s timing. The overwhelming force is already there, a PR disaster in the glare of the World’s media is not required.
A possible weak link of China is the number of students it has studying in the West and their immediate dismissal and relocation to China might cause a problem. Australia 260,000; 369,000 US; 120,000 UK.  (2019)
Therefore, I propose a 10% chance of full mobilisation at his stage, although a surreptitious  activity could be currently happening by the PAP. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests-military-exclusive/exclusive-chinas-internal-security-force-on-frontlines-of-hong-kong-protests-idUSKBN2150JZ
https://www.france24.com/en/20200529-us-uk-step-up-pressure-on-china-over-hong-kong-security-law
https://thehill.com/policy/international/499912-us-uk-australia-canada-oppose-beijings-moves-on-hong-kong
https://www.ft.com/content/795a85b1-621f-4144-bee0-153eb5235943
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-53397673
https://www.dw.com/en/hong-kong-china-us-tensions-put-asias-financial-hub-at-risk/a-53614838
https://thediplomat.com/2020/04/the-latest-target-of-chinas-nationalistic-backlash-chinese-returnees/
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-48445934

Ng, J., Leung C. & Mok, D. (2020). Hong Kong police raid office of poll organizers involved in Saturday’s opposition primary, over suspected data leak from 2013 project. South China Post. Hong Kong. Politics. July 12, 2020. Retrieve from
https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3092742/hong-kong-police-raid-office-poll-organisers-involved Hong Kong police on Friday raided the office of poll organisers involved in the opposition’s primary election a day before the event, aiming to remove computers over a recently alleged data leak from a project seven years ago.
A spokesman from the force said officers from the Cyber Security and Technology Crime Bureau searched an office in Wong Chuk Hang on Friday afternoon after receiving reports about a suspected data leak concerning city residents, including police, that may be linked to criminal hacking. No arrests were made.
Chung Kim-wah, deputy chief executive officer of the Hong Kong Public Opinion Research Institute (PORI), told the Post at 8.30pm that he learned from his colleagues about the police raid.

I am still trying to figure out how to handle this question properly. My current guess is that the best strategy could be to check a brief history of protests along the world and from that improve the outside view. Two questions come to mind: 1) Do legal and political means make protests disappear?
2) Do the use of force do the trick? The answer to 1) is "maybe, but it is probably not particularly effective", while the answer to 2) is "yes, with a high degree of confidence". However this is based on anecdotal evidence, diagonal reading and a few random memories of past events, not on a detailed review of past protests cases. I have a few lectures in the waiting [1,2,3,4,5], but of course if some of you guys could take a look and provide a summary that would be great @Emil @A356 @KitsonJ @Orao  My impression is that Beijing has probably considered these aspects and has some assessment of whether the security law is really going to work or not. Maybe the decision tree is somehow like this: 1) Try the law and check these two things:
  1.a) are protests receding?
  1.b) what is the answer of the international community? 2) If the answer to 1.a) is "no", while for 1.b) there is no substantive backlash, then maybe there is no harm in using the PLA/PAP Things might be tipping towards 2): the HKers have very quickly found a new way to protest with blank pieces of paper, and I must admit that I am amazed at their resourcefulness and creativity, while the international reaction mostly consists of words and easing immigration to the HKers. However there is the eternal problem of which is the time frame: China tends to go ahead relentlessly, but more often than not slowly. Besides, there is another seemingly unrelated factor which could play a role: a future Chinese vaccine, which if developed or mass produced before competitors, will for sure be used as political leverage. This could indeed embolden Beijing to advance any future plans they have for HK. [1] https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/06/why-protests-work/613420/
[2] https://www.jstor.org/stable/4148070?seq=1
[3] https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.soc.012809.102609
[4] https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1467-9248.2008.00771.x
[5] https://www.aclu.org/blog/national-security/global-suppression-protest

Those entities no but China has opened an office of its Security Service in Hong Kong. It is more likely they will let the local riot police deal with protests but the Security Service will haul away leaders. There have been no street protests so far. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jul/08/china-great-firewall-descends-hong-kong-internet-users

I suggest further inquiry, whether inauguration on Wednesday of the "Office of Safeguarding National Security of the Central People's Government of the People's Republic of China in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region" (wow, what a name for a bureau, sounds important) entails the mobilization of People's Armed Police (PAP) staff. https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/07/moment-china-opens-security-office-hong-kong-200708032647026.html "The legislation gives its agents, operating openly in the global financial hub for the first time, enforcement powers."
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests-china-security/china-converts-hong-kong-hotel-into-new-national-security-office-idUSKBN24903Z
Protests leaders leaving. No mass protest so far. Lowering.

Right now I am trying to figure out how to find some specific method to answer this question: it does not matter for the moment if the answer will be accurate or not, it only matters whether I can do a postmortem once the question is resolved and try to improve future forecast of this type. The most direct way to systematize the prediction of a probability is to fermi-ize the answer, which in this case is not that difficult: P = P_pro x P_pla with P_pro the probability of a protest big enough as to overwhelm the local police forces and P_pla the probability of the PLA being mobilize. However it could be more complicated than this because there could be several protest that reach this threshold, in which case we should have something like P = 1 - Sum_n P_{n-pro} X (1- P_pla)^n  with the condition that Sum_n P_{n-pro} = 1 where the complication in the math is to indicate that the probability is better expressed as 1 minus the probability of nothing happening: P_{n-pro} is the probability of having n big enough protest, which sums to 1 (Sum_n P_{n-pro} = 1), and if there are n big protests in total, the probability of the PLA not entering is  (1- P_pla)^n. The core of this question is that P_pro is considered to be high (closer to 1 than to 0), while P_pla was considered to be really low. The PLA troops entering HK could be considered a serious breach of the Sino-British Joint Declaration, but I guess that even this could be subject to interpretation (I did not check the declaration in detail, despite having it around here). The reason why the question is here is to try to assess how likely is that the CCP will decide to cross that red line. Now here there are two balancing acts that are difficult to assess: 1) Do we expect more or less big demonstration as past year? 1.a) In favor of more we have the grit and perseverance of the demonstrators and the incendiary nature of the National Security Law: once and again, every time that the demonstrations seemed to be going to fade, they just kept going. Of course there must be a limit on that, but I am not sure which limit is that. Besides, this is in a sense a fundamental trait of this confrontation: Chinese culture is gritty, very gritty. Both the protestors and the CCP consider this to be a long term struggle where neither side should back down.  Besides, I remember when the LEGCO was taken one year ago, there was the theory that it was a false flag operation. I did not follow suit, so I do not know if there is a consensus about this right now. The problem when dealing with the CCP is that it is simply not possible to discard this type of conspiranoid theories, after all they rose to power partly through these means. 1.b) Against we have the punitive character of the National Security Law, which seems to have already have some effect in the sense of avoiding showing public support for the protest. The approach of the Chinese side here is to be as punitive as possible, but also as vague as possible, so they can use the law for arbitrary political purposes (this is a typical CCP move). 2) The probability of the PLA entering to "save the day" 2.a) In favor we have the fact that the National Security Law is already a "crossing the Rubicon" moment. The threshold for crossing it again should be lower. Besides, a mobilization of the PLA would be viewed very positively by the Chinese citizens on the mainland: I just remember about one year ago, when the incident on the airport happened, how in my Wechat feed several of my contacts were clamoring for an intervention to restore order. This second observation makes me think that if such thing were going to happen it could more likely be linked to the needs of internal mainland politics than by the situation in HK. 2.b) Against we have again the National Security Law itself, which is simply a very ambiguous factor. In principle with it there should be better "legal tools" (to give it some name) to deal with demonstrations and any type of pro-democracy movement within HK. However before the National Security Law there were already a lot of "extrajudicial tools" available to achieve this goal. Again, even here there is a difficult balance to consider. There is also another factor in my mind: the experience with Xinjiang suggest that even in the absence of actual events (in the case of Xinjiang, the protests date from more than 10 years ago), simply the existence of perceived threats will push the current leadership to tighten its grip and issue more punitive measures. Against this factor is the ethno-nationalistic nature of the CCP: measures taken against national minorities, such as the Uyghurs, are less likely to be taken against Han chinese. What's your take on this, @A356 ? Also, @KitsonJ , you seem to always have a good record of previous events to apply the outside view to a problem. China has been trying to integrate Hong Kong for many years. The recent 'Security Law' hints at a speeding up (of the speeding up) of this process. The CCP (Chinese Communist Party) is seizing the opportunity brought about by COVID-19. And recently, they have gained the leverage of hypocrisy due to the BLM protests - making criticisms less valid. In the very short term - there will be marches on July 1 (anniversary of the handover). The Security Law will most likely be passed in the next few days, enabling some form of retaliation. From which Chinese organization and in what form is a difficult question.  There is some evidence that the PAP is already in Hong Kong: 
"Responding to questions from Reuters, the Chinese Defence Ministry said the PAP was not stationed in Hong Kong, while a Hong Kong police spokesman said they 'stress that there is no such visit or observation by any members of the mainland law enforcement agencies'."
"The diplomat and three other foreign envoys, however, estimated that China’s government had ramped up the paramilitary People’s Armed Police (PAP) presence in Hong Kong to as many as 4,000 personnel - far more than previously known estimates."
"taken together with the numbers of PLA troops that also expanded last year, the estimated 12,000-strong force marks the largest ever Chinese security deployment in Hong Kong." [1] "The law will also establish a new security agency in the territory to enforce the security restrictions, and Beijing will create its own separate security arm in Hong Kong, empowered to investigate special cases and collect intelligence, according to a summary issued by China’s legislature." Furthermore, polls show a decline in support for the protests, and the 1 July one may involve fewer people and violence, lowering the incentive to used armed police [3]. COVID-19 could also prevent action.  If I was in the CCP and had their vision, I would use fake protesters to instigate some extreme damage e.g. fires in areas that do not put people's lives at risk. This would turn more people against the protests and give the mobilization of Chinese security agencies validity.   This week should be a good indicator for the next 6 months. The question asks whether there will be any active engagement between the PLA or PAP and Hong Kong protesters within the next seven months. Firstly, we should note that neither the PLA nor the PAP have ever been used in Hong Kong since the handover. Any change of this policy would cause domestic and international outrage in light of the 'one country, two systems' principle. Furthermore, China, conscious of its soft power, will be keen to avoid any Tiananmen-style images going around the world. However, engagement by either the PLA or PAP would not necessarily be as violent as the Tiananmen massacre. They could simply act as reinforcements for the Hong Kong Police Force (HKPF). As Carrie Lam has said, the HKPF has been 'outnumbered' in recent protests. These comments, in addition to comments by the PRC that it would 'not sit idly by' have created a rhetoric that opens the door to a future mobilisation of the PLA or PAP in Hong Kong. Considering that China wants to be seen as a responsible actor, the only real motivation for such a mobilisation would be continued and out of control protests. The recent actions by the PRC and Hong Kong legislatures provide ample reason for such protests. China has doubled the size of its contingent in Hong Kong, which notably now includes the PAP, which has been used in similar situations in Tibet and Xinjiang (the major difference lying in the fact that Hong Kong is a SAR). Mobilisation of these forces would, under the current rule of law, have to be requested by the Hong Kong government; a possible scenario, considering Carrie Lam's allegiance to the PRC and her comments on the HKPF being outnumbered. Lastly, the role of Covid-19 should be understood. Amidst the ongoing crisis countries have turned inwards, providing an opportunity for Beijing to move forward on some of its key ambitions with a weaker international backlash. Evaluating all of these arguments, 35% at this time seems adequate.

I’d say the odds just inched up a little. Uncle Xi installing people less forgiving of dissent. From WSJ:
“Beijing replaced the head of its Hong Kong policy-making agency with a political veteran and onetime law enforcer with close ties to President Xi Jinping, who has demanded fresh efforts to tighten control over the protest-racked city. Xia Baolong, vice chairman of a national political-advisory body and a former provincial leader, was appointed director of the Chinese government’s Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office, according to a brief report published Thursday by China’s state-run Xinhua News Agency. The 67-year-old replaced Zhang Xiaoming, who was demoted to deputy director with responsibilities over day-to-day operations at the office, a ministerial-level agency that oversees governance in the two former colonies, according to Xinhua. The appointment of Mr. Xia, who has no experience in Hong Kong policy-making and is more than a decade older than his predecessor, comes just weeks after Beijing installed a new chief of its liaison office in the former British colony. It extends a shake-up in the Communist Party apparatus overseeing governance of Hong Kong, where anti-Beijing protests over the past eight months have posed a challenge to Mr. Xi’s leadership and remains a source of concern even as a continuing coronavirus outbreak became the priority for China’s leaders. Since mass protests erupted in Hong Kong in June, broadly targeting Beijing’s growing influence over the semiautonomous city, the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office has been accused of underestimating the depth of public discontent that has fueled the unrest and led to a landslide defeat of pro-Beijing politicians at local district elections in November.“

It is highly unlikely that the PRC will utilize PLA and/or PAP troops in Hong Kong (10%). Thus far, Hong Kong's police force (or counter-protesters) has effectively contained the demonstrations. With only a handful of fatal casualties to date, there seems to be no need for China's more robust military forces to be mobilized in HK. Xi Jinping remembers well the results of armed forces being mobilized to quell demonstrations in Tiananmen Square and hopes to avoid that at all costs. Although the PAP has been successful with its operations in Xinjiang and Tibet its mobilization in a Special Administrative Region (SAR) such as HK would represent a more real and symbolic violation of its own "One Country, Two Systems" policy. China's economy is slowing and the PRC is currently scrambling to address its Coronavirus population. Damaging its reputation with HK, especially after it received support from the US President, might have disastrous blowback on its economy via trade. It still has to iron out trade deals with the US as well. There are many variables regarding the US general election this year, so any hasty moves that would cause President Trump to criticize China might manifest themselves for 4 more years (if he is re-elected in 2020).  Overall, there are too many variables that delay official PLA/PAP action being taken in HK. A slowing economy, waning protester activity heading into early 2020, the ramifications of the spreading coronavirus, and ongoing trade negotiations with the US greatly prevent the PRC from taking any harsh actions against HK in the near future.

The PLA and PAP would be mobilized under two possible conditions[1]:
(A) The Hong Kong government ask for help from the PLA garrisons already stationed there due to a public order breakdown OR
(B) China’s National People’s Congress Standing Committee declares a state of emergency, allowing Beijing to react how it deems necessary At the current time, (A) does not seem likely to occur imminently. There are no widespread reports of the local police being overwhelmed by protestor action and reinforcements being required. When unarmed PLA forces did leave their barracks to help with street clean up, the Hong Kong government condemned this action and said it did not ask for help.[2]  (A) would become more likely if the protests become more violent, meaning the police find them harder to resist and contain, or if the police force numbers decline due to individual officers leaving the force. This could occur due to public perception of the police being particularly low [3][4], which may affect morale. (B) would likely cause international outcry so is probably a last resort. There are a number of actions China could take first including infiltration of Hong Kong police force (some think this has already taken place) [3], pressuring Hong Kong businesses and government to support the police and enact legal injunctions against protestors [5] and shows of power, such as the maneuvers in Shenzhen.[6]  That said, certain political could increase the risk of B, such as any wavering by the Hong Kong government on the protestors’ fifth demand (resignation of Carrie Lam and the implementation of universal suffrage)[7]. This situation would be considered extreme by China as it could lead to the start of true independence of Hong Kong, and a militaristic response becomes more likely, such as was seen in Catalonia when an independence referendum took place.[8] As of January 2020, neither A or B seem likely, in the near term, but the time horizon for this question is long. A lot depends on the protestors’ persistence and whether they are willing to escalate.  Given the long period the protests have been ongoing so far, and the sense that these protests are driven by young people’s desperation[9], escalation does seem likely.  My initial forecast is based on:
    • A 70% chance of escalation
    • A 20% chance that this will eventually lead to PLA and PAP deployment
    • 70% * 20% = 14% This forecast will be increased if:
    • Protests become more violent
    • News coverage shows that police seem unable to contain and control the protests
    • Police personnel numbers fall and / or recruitment stalls
    • Carrie Lam resigns
    • The HK government make concessions towards universal suffrage, or implement significant electoral changes [1] https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/chinese-state-media-praises-hong-kong-police-restraint
[2] https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1492648-20191116.htm?archive_date=2019-11-16
[3] https://www.pri.org/stories/2019-11-06/china-s-internal-suppression-troops-have-plans-hong-kong
[4] https://www.hongkongfp.com/2019/12/07/hong-kong-police-receive-lowest-public-satisfaction-rating-among-disciplinary-forces-survey/
[5] https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3023322/will-beijing-deploy-troops-hong-kong-taiwan-can-provide
[6] https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/china-army-hongkong/
[7] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Hong_Kong_protests#Objectives
[8] https://www.pri.org/stories/2017-10-01/spanish-riot-police-fight-suppress-catalonias-defiant-independence-vote
[9] https://edition.cnn.com/2019/07/02/asia/hong-kong-protests-anger-intl/index.html

Efforts seem to be dying down. The Hong Kong Police (backed by the Chinese national army) will continue to quell protests until they taper out. On the other hand, all it takes is one renewed surge from the protestors to trigger military action.
I think they will be cautious, but it is not beyond the scope of possibility.

The three articles linked in the question are all from last year, spanning about six months. Presuming the PLA and PAP have not yet been involved, in spite of very tense conditions, I think the chance of it happening in the next ~ 11 months is quite low, but obviously not zero. It's not obvious to me that this question will have an easy answer, as I'm not convinced that a mobilization would necessarily be obvious. Could PLA or PAP troops be activated in Hong Kong police uniforms, or without uniform insignia of any kind? Here I recall Russian aggression (or supposed Russian aggression) in the Crimea, where their troops were (supposedly, depending on what news you believe) fighting without flags or insignia. Could that happen here? Who knows...

Several points China is prepared to put up with it at present as long as it does not spread. It is not spreading and there is no reason that it will for now. Then if Trump wins, then China will be very reluctant as it would be worried about more trade wars, if Trump loses all international stops are off.

Often amazed at (Official) Chinese patience. Believe low for PLA. Probably higher for PAP? Also trying to maintain perspective for Taiwan...
“Patience is a bitter plant, but its fruit is sweet.”
“A little impatience will spoil great plans.”
